**Northern corn leaf blight (NCLB) is caused by the fungus Setosphaeria turcica. Symptoms usually appear first on the lower leaves**

***Disease development is favored by extended periods (>6 hours) of leaf wetness (rain or dew) and moderate temperatures (17-27.2°C)***

Source:https://cropprotectionnetwork.org/resources/articles/diseases/northern-corn-leaf-blight-of-corn
source.1d84cc35:
**Gray leaf spot, caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis, occurs virtually every growing season. If conditions favor disease development, economic losses can occur. Symptoms first appear on lower leaves about two to three weeks before tasseling**

**Infection of corn leaves and disease development are favored by warm (26°C), humid (>90% for 12+ hours) weather**

Source:https://cropprotectionnetwork.org/resources/articles/diseases/gray-leaf-spot-of-corn

**Common rust is caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi and occurs every growing season. It is seldom a concern in hybrid corn. Rust pustules usually first appear in late June.**

**Rust development is favored by high humidity with night temperatures of 18-21°C and moderate daytime temperatures. The disease is usually more severe on seed corn.**

Source:https://cropprotectionnetwork.org/resources/articles/diseases/common-rust-of-corn
